northeast.tip: Wait until soil temperature reaches 60°F (15.5°C) before planting warm-season crops like tomatoes and peppers
Consider using raised beds to improve drainage in heavy clay soils common in the Northeast
Start cool-season crops like peas and lettuce as soon as soil can be worked in spring
Plant fall crops in August for harvest before first frost
Apply row covers to extend growing season in spring and fall

southeast.tip: Start heat-tolerant varieties in spring for summer harvests
Plant cool-season crops in September/October for fall and winter harvests
Provide afternoon shade for lettuce and greens during hot summers
Consider drip irrigation to reduce fungal diseases in humid climate
Monitor for pests year-round as mild winters allow pest populations to persist

midwest.tip: Wait until after last frost date to plant warm-season crops
Use cold frames or plastic tunnels to extend growing season by up to 4 weeks
Plant cool-season crops like spinach and peas as soon as soil can be worked
Choose short-season varieties in northern areas with shorter growing seasons
Consider mulching to retain soil moisture during hot, dry summers

southwest.tip: Plant heat-sensitive crops like lettuce and peas in fall for winter harvest
Use shade cloth during summer months to protect plants from intense sun
Consider deep watering less frequently to encourage deep root growth
In low desert areas, avoid planting tomatoes when nighttime temperatures exceed 85°F (29°C)

west.tip: Plant drought-tolerant Mediterranean herbs like rosemary and thyme in full sun
Consider establishing plants before summer heat to develop strong root systems
Use mulch to conserve soil moisture in dry climate
In coastal areas, choose varieties resistant to powdery mildew due to foggy conditions
Plant fall garden in August/September for extended harvests

northwest.tip: Choose cool-season crops and rain-tolerant varieties
Start seeds indoors to get a head start during rainy spring
Use raised beds to improve drainage in rainy climate
Consider row covers or cloches to protect from persistent rain
Plant warm-season crops like tomatoes in warmest, sunniest garden locations

north.tip: Choose fast-maturing varieties to account for shorter growing season
Use cloches or polytunnels to extend growing season by 3-4 weeks
Start seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost date
Consider planting in sheltered locations to protect from wind
Choose hardy varieties that tolerate cooler temperatures and shorter days

midlands.tip: Avoid planting frost-sensitive crops before mid-May
Consider fleece or cloches for early and late season protection
Plant green manures in autumn to improve soil structure and fertility
Start brassicas indoors in July for autumn and winter harvests
Consider raised beds to improve drainage during wet periods

south.tip: Take advantage of longer growing season by succession planting
Start tender crops like tomatoes and cucumbers after mid-April
Consider drought-resistant varieties for dry summer periods
Plant winter vegetables in July/August for autumn and winter harvests
Mulch to conserve moisture during dry summer months

atlantic.tip: Choose short-season varieties that can mature within 100 days
Use raised beds to improve drainage in areas with high rainfall
Start seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost date
Plant cool-season crops as soon as soil can be worked in spring
Consider row covers to protect from late spring and early fall frosts

central.tip: Wait until soil temperature reaches 15°C (60°F) before planting heat-loving crops
Use season extenders like cold frames or tunnels in spring and fall
Start seeds indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost date
Select varieties rated for your hardiness zone
Consider planting a fall garden in July for harvest before first frost

prairie.tip: Use mulch to conserve moisture and moderate soil temperature
Consider wind protection for garden beds in open areas
Plant cool-season crops in early April and again in August
Choose fast-maturing varieties (60-80 days) for areas with short growing seasons

west_coast.tip: Take advantage of mild climate with extended planting seasons
Use raised beds to improve drainage in rainy coastal regions
Consider planting fall and winter gardens for year-round harvests
Choose rain-tolerant varieties in coastal areas
Plant cool-season crops throughout fall for winter harvest

northern.tip: Plant cool-season vegetables during the dry season (May-September)
Choose varieties adapted to tropical conditions with high humidity tolerance
Use shade cloth during the hottest months to protect plants
Consider raised beds for better drainage during wet season
Plant heat-loving crops at the beginning of the wet season

central.tip: Choose drought-tolerant varieties for hot, dry summers
Use mulch extensively to conserve soil moisture
Plant cool-season crops in March-April for winter harvest
Consider shade protection for plants during hottest summer months
Use drip irrigation to conserve water in arid climate

southern.tip: Plant frost-sensitive crops after mid-October (after risk of frost has passed)
Start cool-season crops in February-March for autumn and winter harvest
Consider wind protection in coastal and exposed areas
Plant heat-loving crops like tomatoes and peppers in November
Use cloches or row covers to protect from late spring frosts
